newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soybeans close mostly firm on weather concern.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soybeans close mostly firm on weather concern.

text.p: CBOT soybean futures closed mixed but mostly firm on renewed concerns about weather patterns in the U.S. Midwest, traders said.
"It's up on a combination of things. The word frost was a little scary and it's up on the fact we continue dry," said Mark Cermak of O'Connor and Co.
Meteorologists early Tuesday disagreed on forecasts for much cooler weather next week.
"Right now there's no cool air threat to end the growing season," Cermak said.
Weather forecasters saw dry weather early this week. Such conditions could be hampering soybean pod filling.
But there were prospects for rain later this week in the eastern and southern portions of the soy belt.

Joel Burgio, meteorologist for Weather Services Corp said temperatures were expected to peak in the low 80s (degrees Fahrenheit) across much of the region but long-range forecasts indicated a Canadian cold front would push across the region this weekend, bringing much cooler temperatures.
September soybeans were hit by long liquidation, weak cash basis markets and on the early advance of soy harvest.
Soybeans closed 3-1/2 cents per bushel lower to 2-1/4 higher, with September down 3-1/2 at $8.11.
New crop November soybeans continued to flirt with the $8.00 per bushel per mark, an area of stiff technical resistance, the traders said. The session high for November was $8.03 and the low $7.95.
November ended near the day's low at $7.95-1/2 per bushel, up one cent from Friday's settlement.
Soybean futures volume was estimated at 35,000 contracts, up from 29,726 Friday.

In soybean options, Produce Grain bought 500 November $7.75 puts and sold 500 November $7.50 puts, the traders said. FIMAT Futures sold 400 november $8.00 puts, Continental Grain bought 300 january $8.25 calls, sold 300 January $9.25 calls and sold 300 January $7.50 puts, sources said.
Soybean options volume was estimated at 13,000 contracts, down from 14,665 Friday.
